Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a message from Mia: “Which night should we do our date? I’m free all week!” I smile, picturing her excitement, and start typing a reply. Before I hit send, another notification pops up—my activist group’s chat. “Urgent: We have one hour to add signatures to the petition before it goes to the senator. Every name counts!” My heart pounds. I know how much this policy change means, how hard we’ve worked, and how my voice could make a difference. But Mia’s been looking forward to this week, hoping we’d finally have time just for us, no distractions. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—her hope for connection, my responsibility to the cause. My fingers hover over the screen, torn between the promise I made to her and the commitment I feel to the movement. I can’t ignore either, but I can’t do both at once. My chest tightens as I try to decide which part of me to honor in this moment.
